<script type="text/javascript">
var main_site_url = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
var maindomain_lang = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
function getParameterByName(name, url) {
		if(url == null){
		  url = window.location.href;
		}
	    name = name.replace(/[\[\]]/g, '\\$&');
	    var regex = new RegExp('[?&]' + name + '(=([^&#]*)|&|#|$)'),
		results = regex.exec(url);
	    if (!results) return null;
	    if (!results[2]) return '';
	    return decodeURIComponent(results[2].replace(/\+/g, ' '));
	}
	var container_q = getParameterByName('container');
	var d_lang = 'en';	
	if(container_q != '' && container_q != null){	    
	    sessionStorage.setItem('container',container_q);
	    	    location.href = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/malicious-packages-in-pypi';
	}
</script>

	<title>Six Malicious Python Packages in the PyPI Targeting Windows Users</title>
	<meta name="description" content="Malicious packages on PyPI copy W4SP attacks to steal users’ credentials and crypto wallet data. This incident illustrates issues in open-source ecosystems." />
	<link rel="canonical" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/malicious-packages-in-pypi/" />

	<meta property="og:description" content="Malicious packages on PyPI copy W4SP attacks to steal users’ credentials and crypto wallet data. This incident illustrates issues in open-source ecosystems." />

<meta property="og:post_length" content="2970"/>

<meta property="og:category" content="Threat Research"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cloud-cybersecurity-research/"/>
<meta property="og:category_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/"/>
<meta property="og:author" content="Shaul Ben Hai"/>
<meta property="og:authorlink" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/author/"/>
<meta property="og:author_image_link" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/11/unit-news-meta.svg"/>

<meta property="og:post_image" content="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/Cloud-21-illustration_black.png"/>
<script type="application/ld+json">{"@context":"https:\/\/schema.org","@type":"BlogPosting","headline":"Six Malicious Python Packages in the PyPI Targeting Windows Users","name":"Six Malicious Python Packages in the PyPI Targeting Windows Users","description":"Malicious packages on PyPI copy W4SP attacks to steal users\u2019 credentials and crypto wallet data. This incident illustrates issues in open-source ecosystems.","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/malicious-packages-in-pypi\/","mainEntityOfPage":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/malicious-packages-in-pypi\/","datePublished":"July 11, 2023","articleBody":"Executive Summary\r\nIn March 2023, Unit 42 researchers discovered six malicious packages on the Python Package Index (PyPI) package manager. The malicious packages were intended to steal Windows users\u2019 application credentials, personal data and tracking information for their crypto wallets. The attack was an attempted imitation of the attack group W4SP, which had previously launched several supply chain attacks using malicious packages.\r\n\r\nWe will discuss the ease with which threat actors can use malicious packages to release malicious code in an open-source ecosystem. The behavior we observed is not an organized campaign planned by an attack group, but most likely an imitator who read technical reports of previous campaigns to execute their own attack. We will walk through a technical analysis of the malicious code and unravel what the threat actor tried to achieve in the attack.\r\n\r\nWe will describe the indicators used by Palo Alto Networks Prisma Cloud modules that identified the malicious packages discussed here. Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections from open-source packages containing malicious code via Prisma Cloud.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nRelated Unit 42 Topics\r\nCloud, Python, Open Source\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nOverview\r\nMalicious packages are software components that were intentionally designed to cause harm to computer systems or the data they process. Such packages can be distributed through various means, including phishing emails, compromised websites or even legitimate software repositories.\r\n\r\nMalicious packages can have far-reaching consequences, from surreptitiously pilfering sensitive data to causing system disruptions and even assuming control over entire systems. Moreover, these nefarious packages possess the ability to spread to other interconnected systems, instigating widespread damage and impeding productivity. Thus, it is important to exercise utmost caution when engaging in software downloads and installations, especially when the source is unfamiliar or untrusted.\r\n\r\nBy remaining vigilant and discerning, users can safeguard their systems and prevent potential harm from threat actors infiltrating their technological environment.\r\nNew Malicious Packages Discovered in PyPI\r\nIn March 2023, Prisma Cloud researchers discovered six malicious packages on the PyPI package manager targeting Windows users. The malicious packages were intended to steal application credentials, personal data and cryptocurrency wallet information.\r\n\r\nOur Prisma Cloud engine, designed to detect malicious PyPI packages, identified several packages with suspicious attributes that were uploaded within a short time frame:\r\n\r\n \tThe packages lacked an associated GitHub repository, which is commonly found with legitimate packages. This could indicate a desire to hide the code from view. This, coupled with a limited number of downloads, further raised our suspicions.\r\n \tWhen executed, the packages performed malicious actions such as collecting sensitive data and sending it to third-party URLs.\r\n \tThe packages contained a malicious code pattern (as will be demonstrated later), which was detected by our engine.\r\n \tBecause the package authors were newly created, had only uploaded one package, and did not provide supporting information such as links to other projects or to any repository, they were not considered reputable.\r\n \tFinally, the usernames of the packages\u2019 author(s) were created within minutes of each other, following a distinctive pattern (e.g., Anne1337, Richard1337). Each of these usernames had uploaded only a single package.\r\n\r\nThe second stage of the attack was similar to previous attacks we have seen by the W4SP attack group. This group specializes in exploiting vulnerabilities in the open-source ecosystem, targeting organizations and spreading malware. Their primary goal is to gain unauthorized access to sensitive information, such as user credentials and financial data. They often use automated tools to scan for vulnerabilities and attempt to exploit them. In addition to traditional attacks, W4SP attackers were also seen executing supply chain attacks.\r\nFindings\r\nPrisma Cloud engine detected the packages that were marked as potentially containing malicious code. Each package contained a link to a suspicious remote URL, trying to download contents after having been uploaded individually by a single user.\r\n\r\nThe users for each uploaded package, whose usernames were created just before the upload, didn\u2019t have any history of previously uploading packages. Each package reached hundreds of downloads, until they and the fraudulent user accounts that uploaded them were removed by PyPI due to our research team reporting the abuse.\r\n\r\nWe analyzed the code and tried to track down the package authors. We discovered a pattern in every package author\u2019s username where they used \u201c1337\u201d as a suffix, which indicates that some automatic process created those users, as shown in Table 1. Figure 1 shows an author page for one of these usernames.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nPackage Name\r\nAuthor\u00a0\r\nMalicious Link\r\nNumber of Downloads\r\n\r\n\r\nligitgays\r\nAnne1337\r\nhxxps:\/\/paste.bingner[.]com\/paste\/o27gb\/raw\r\n191\r\n\r\n\r\nxboxredeemer\r\nRichard1337\r\nhxps:\/\/paste.bingner[.]com\/paste\/47rpu\/raw\r\n160\r\n\r\n\r\nsyntax-init\r\nDebbie1337\r\nhxxps:\/\/paste.bingner[.]com\/paste\/q77t3\/raw\r\n140\r\n\r\n\r\nxboxlivepy\r\nChristopher1337\r\nhxxps:\/\/paste.bingner[.]com\/paste\/jr7ow\/raw\r\n153\r\n\r\n\r\nLigitkidss\r\nSara1337\r\nhxxps:\/\/paste.bingner[.]com\/paste\/9mzzs\/raw\r\n158\r\n\r\n\r\ntls-python\r\nKevin1337\r\nhxxps:\/\/paste.bingner[.]com\/paste\/97vnn\/raw\r\n240\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTable 1. Malicious package findings.\r\n\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_129040\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 1. An author page on PyPI.[\/caption]\r\nThe Attack: Custom Package Entry Point\r\nThe attack was similar to previous attacks we have seen by the W4SP attack group, which was covered in detail in the Bleeping Computer article, \u201cDevs targeted by W4SP Stealer malware in malicious PyPi packages.\u201d These similarities led us to believe this was a copycat attack.\r\n\r\nThere were aspects of this case that were less complex than we would expect for a true W4SP attack, for example:\r\n\r\n \tThere was no targeting of any organization.\r\n \tThe malicious packages did not use typosquatting for common popular packages, as expected for W4SP attacks.\r\n \tThe second phase of the attack was not encrypted. In the true attacks from W4SP, this phase was encrypted and it made detection more difficult.\r\n \tMost of the code used by W4SP for previous attacks was already available for download, so it could be easily accessed and repurposed.\r\n\r\nIn the previous attack, W4SP Stealer was delivered as a second stage payload downloaded from a free file hosting service, which allowed the attacker to avoid detection at the package repository itself.\r\n\r\nRather than containing overtly malicious code, these packages were crafted to have specific entry points that would be triggered during the installation or execution process. By leveraging free file hosting services and employing custom entry points, the attackers aimed to remain undetected, posing a significant challenge to security professionals and researchers tasked with detecting and mitigating such threats.\r\n\r\nThese attacks are easy to implement and can be launched with little security expertise. However, they can be very effective, as the installation process automatically executes the attack as opposed to a threat actor needing to launch the attack when the imported module is used.\r\n\r\nWhen a software developer wants to use a Python package they have to perform two actions. The first is to install the package, and the second is to import or declare in the code to use it. As we discuss in the next section, the attack code actually starts in the installation file (setup.py), which means that the attack is already carried out during the installation of the package.\r\n\r\nIn the case we investigated, the attacker called themself @EVIL$ STEALER. However, the attacker\u2019s name changed with every attack. Below is the collection of names, as found in the code signature:\r\n\r\n \tANGEL Stealer\r\n \tCelestial Stealer\r\n \tFade Stealer\r\n \tLeaf $tealer\r\n \tPURE Stealer\r\n \tSatan Stealer\r\n \t@skid Stealer\r\n\r\nMalicious Code\r\nThe setup.py file was the same in all packages and contained the following code snippet that downloads content from a remote URL before executing it:\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_129042\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 2. Setup.py (first stage) malicious code.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFigure 2 (above) shows the following activities:\r\n\r\n \tThe attacker uses the _ffile object to create a temporary file, and the contents of the file are written using the write method.\r\n\r\n \tThe usage of a temporary file with the NamedTemporaryFile function is a well-known technique to hide malicious code from detection by antivirus software or other security measures.\r\n\r\n\r\n \tThe file's contents are obtained by downloading the contents of a URL using the urlopen function from the urllib.request module, and then executes the contents of the file using the exec function.\r\n \tAfter the contents of the temporary file have been written, the file is closed and an attempt is made to execute it using the start command in the system shell. If this is successful, the setup function is called to create the package.\r\n\r\n \tThe attacker then uses the start command to start the Python engine's executable (pythonw.exe).\r\n \tThis executable will then execute the script file that is passed as a parameter. Since that malicious package targeted Windows users, if the script file is not signed, it will not be subject to SmartScreen (Windows security feature to detect and prevent the execution of potentially malicious files) or signature checking.\r\n \tThis means it will execute malicious code on a target computer, even if the target computer has SmartScreen and signature checking enabled.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Second Stage: W4SP Stealer\r\nAccording to our research, for the second stage, the attacker used a configured version of W4SP Stealer 1.1.6. This version is similar to previous ones where the code imports several libraries, including requests, Crypto.Cipher, json and sqlite3. Then, it uses various techniques to extract and decrypt stored browser credentials, including passwords and cookies, and sends this information to a Discord webhook.\r\n\r\nThis stage was similar within all of the malicious packages found. The W4SP Stealer is well known by the cybersecurity community. This section will give a short overview.\r\n\r\nThe main body of the code defines a class DATA_BLOB, which is used to store data for the CryptUnprotectData function. This function decrypts a Windows Data Protection API (DPAPI)-protected value, which is used to store sensitive data such as passwords and API keys. The code attempts to decrypt a value using the CryptUnprotectData and DecryptValue functions, and then sends it to a remote server via a Discord webhook, as shown in Figure 3.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_129044\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 3. Attempts to decrypt a Windows Data Protection API (DPAPI)-protected value.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nThe figures below show several examples from the malicious code in which the attacker tries to collect information about the victim. In Figure 4, the attacker tries to collect information about the victim including IP address, username, country and country code.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_129046\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 4. Code that retrieves information about the user's IP address, location and username among other things.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nIn Figure 5, the attacker interacts with the Discord API to retrieve a user's friend list and extract information about their owned badge.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_129048\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 5. Code to retrieve a list of a user's friends on Discord.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nLater in code, they try to use a Discord webhook prepared in advance (shown in Figure 6) and then they try to send the victim information via HTTP requests to the associated Discord channel.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_129050\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 6. Discord webhook.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nFinally, as shown in Figure 7, the attacker tries to verify whether the victim's machine is suitable for carrying out the attack. If it\u2019s determined that the machine is suitable, the DETECTED variable will be set to true and the information from the victim's machine will be sent to the remote server.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_129052\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 7. Code searching for cookies.[\/caption]\r\nPyPI as a Convenient Platform for Uploading Malicious Packages\r\nWithin the realm of PyPI, which is a revered and widely embraced repository that hosts a staggering number of Python packages, a disconcerting reality has emerged. The repository's unrivaled popularity has inadvertently attracted the attention of unscrupulous entities, fervently seeking to exploit its vast user base by surreptitiously disseminating malicious packages.\r\n\r\nThis distressing trend poses a paramount challenge, as the decentralized nature of PyPI renders the monitoring and detection of these malevolent entities an arduous endeavor. The ramifications of falling victim to such nefarious packages are profound, posing severe consequences for unsuspecting users and enterprises alike, such as data, credential or crypto theft. Hence, fortifying the safety and security of PyPI's package ecosystem assumes a critical imperative, necessitating the implementation of robust countermeasures to combat this persistent threat.\r\n\r\nAs a result of this, it was not surprising that on May 20, 2023, PyPI announced that they temporarily suspended the registration and upload of new packages due to a concerning rise in malicious activities, malicious users and projects on the platform. Unfortunately, no specific information about the nature of the malware or the threat actors involved has been disclosed at this time.\r\n\r\nThis decision to freeze new user and project registrations reflects the ongoing challenges software registries like PyPI face, as they have become attractive targets for attackers seeking to compromise developer environments and tamper with the software supply chain.\r\nConclusion\r\nThe rise and prevalence of open-source software and the proliferation of package managers have made it easier than ever for attackers to slip these dangerous packages into unsuspecting systems. With software becoming increasingly pervasive in our daily lives, the threat of malicious packages has become more significant. Attackers can disguise these packages as legitimate software and exploit vulnerabilities in unsuspecting systems, causing significant damage such as data theft, system shutdown and network control.\r\n\r\nTo combat this threat, software developers and organizations must prioritize software security in their development process. Implementing robust security measures, such as code reviews, automated testing and penetration testing can help identify and remediate vulnerabilities before deployment. Additionally, staying up to date with security patches and updates can prevent attackers from exploiting known vulnerabilities.\r\n\r\nIn addition to technical measures, increasing awareness and education around software security can also help mitigate the risk of malicious packages. Regular training for developers, IT staff and end users on best security practices (e.g., password hygiene and suspicious email identification) can help prevent successful attacks. The collective effort of security professionals, developers and end users is necessary to ensure that malicious packages are identified and prevented from causing harm to systems and networks.\r\n\r\nPublishing technical reports about malware and malicious packages also plays a critical role in advancing our understanding of these threats and improving our ability to protect against them. Technical reports provide an in-depth analysis of the behavior and functionality of malware, which helps researchers and security professionals develop more effective countermeasures. Additionally, sharing technical details about malware can help organizations stay up to date with the latest threats and vulnerabilities, allowing them to improve their security posture and reduce the risk of cyberattacks.\r\nPalo Alto Networks Product Protections\r\nPrisma Cloud Runtime Protection Solution \r\n\r\nPrisma Cloud runtime defenses involve a configurable set of features that provide the identification of specified and predictive protections for cloud virtual machines, containers and serverless functions. Predictive protections include capabilities like determining when a cloud or container instance executes an unknown process or creates an unexpected network socket.\r\n\r\nThreat-based protections include capabilities like detecting when malware is added to a workload, or when a workload connects to a botnet. This detection of malicious binaries is made possible through the integration of the Palo Alto Networks WildFire cloud-based malware protection engine. These runtime incidents can also be detected predeployment, using the Image Analysis Sandbox.\r\n\r\nPrisma Cloud Malicious Package Solution\r\n\r\nPrisma Cloud offers an advanced end-to-end cybersecurity solution that encompasses a comprehensive suite of proactive measures designed to safeguard Prisma customers against a wide array of potential attacks, mitigating risks well in advance of their public exposure.\r\n\r\nAt the heart of this cutting-edge defense system lies the Prisma CVE Viewer, a dynamic resource that operates in real-time, continuously updated to reflect the latest threat landscape.\r\n\r\nIncorporating a unique identification system known as Prisma-IDs, this viewer serves as a central repository for public vulnerabilities meticulously unearthed by our diligent research team. Leveraging this proprietary identifier, it bridges the gap for vulnerabilities that have yet to receive a Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) ID, ensuring no security gaps go unnoticed or unaddressed. Moreover, the Prisma CVE Viewer diligently archives any malicious packages discovered by our expert researchers, empowering Prisma customers with unparalleled visibility into potential threats lurking within their software supply chain.\r\n\r\nAs shown in Figure 8, by arming customers with Prisma-IDs and equipping them with preemptive protection, Prisma Cloud protects against possible exploits before they have an opportunity to materialize. This robust security approach serves as a formidable deterrent against supply chain attacks, proactively thwarting threats and preserving the integrity and resilience of our customers' systems and infrastructure.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_129054\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 8. Prisma Cloud detection.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nOn top of that, the new Prisma Cloud CI\/CD Security module (shown in Figure 9) offers comprehensive protection against emerging methods of executing code in CI pipelines and developers\u2019 environments through malicious software dependencies (e.g., dependency confusion, typosquatting and compromised known packages). This is done by analyzing the different settings, configurations and interconnections of the various systems across the software delivery pipelines, such as the version control and CI systems.\r\n\r\n[caption id=\"attachment_129056\" align=\"aligncenter\" width=\"900\"] Figure 9. Prisma Cloud CI\/CD Security module.[\/caption]\r\n\r\nCortex EDR analytics\r\n\r\nCortex XDR provides EDR analytics capabilities on top of Cortex XDR agents, thus providing analytics-based detection capabilities for runtime command and control (C2) detection of malicious Python packages being used at runtime. An example for EDR analytics C2 coverage is discussed in our Cortex XDR technical documentation. See the Variant subsection \u201cUNIX LOLBIN process connected to a rare external host\u201d under the \"A process connected to a rare external host\" section.\r\nIndicators of Compromise\r\nMalicious Packages\r\n\r\n \tligitgays\r\n \txboxredeemer\r\n \tsyntax-init\r\n \txboxlivepy\r\n \tLigitkidss\r\n \tTls-python\r\n\r\n\r\nMalicious URLs\r\n\r\n \thxxps:\/\/paste.bingner[.]com\/paste\/o27gb\/raw\r\n \thxps:\/\/paste.bingner[.]com\/paste\/47rpu\/raw\r\n \thxxps:\/\/paste.bingner[.]com\/paste\/q77t3\/raw\r\n \thxxps:\/\/paste.bingner[.]com\/paste\/jr7ow\/raw\r\n \thxxps:\/\/paste.bingner[.]com\/paste\/9mzzs\/raw\r\n \thxxps:\/\/paste.bingner[.]com\/paste\/97vnn\/raw\r\n\r\nMalicious Users\r\n\r\n \tAnne1337\r\n \tRichard1337\r\n \tDebbie1337\r\n \tChristopher1337\r\n \tSara1337\r\n \tKevin1337\r\n\r\nUpdated July 14, 2023, at 9:15 a.m. PT to add more context to the code in Figure 2.\u00a0","publisher":{"@type":"Organization","@id":"#panworg"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","url":"https:\/\/unit42.paloaltonetworks.com\/wp-content\/uploads\/2024\/06\/11_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-300x300.jpg","width":300,"height":300},"speakable":{"@type":"SpeakableSpecification","xPath":["\/html\/head\/title","\/html\/head\/meta[@name='description']\/@content"]},"author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Shaul Ben Hai"}]}</script><link rel='stylesheet' id='crayon-css' href='https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/plugins/crayon-syntax-highlighter/css/min/crayon.min.css?ver=_2.7.2_beta' media='all' />

.wp-block-co-authors-plus-coauthors.is-layout-flow [class*=wp-block-co-authors-plus]{display:inline}

</style>
<style id='co-authors-plus-avatar-style-inline-css'>

<script>var $ = jQuery;</script>

    <script type="text/javascript">
    ;(function(win, doc, style, timeout) {
    var STYLE_ID = 'at-body-style';
    function getParent() {
    return doc.getElementsByTagName('head')[0];
    }
    function addStyle(parent, id, def) {
        if (!parent) {
        return;
        }
        var style = doc.createElement('style');
        style.id = id;
        style.innerHTML = def;
        parent.appendChild(style);
    }
    function removeStyle(parent, id) {
        if (!parent) {
            return;
        }
        var style = doc.getElementById(id);
        if (!style) {
            return;
        }
        parent.removeChild(style);
    }
    addStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID, style);
    setTimeout(function() {
    removeStyle(getParent(), STYLE_ID);
    }, timeout);
    }(window, document, "body {visibility:hidden !important}", 3000));
    </script>

            <script src="https://assets.adobedtm.com/9273d4aedcd2/0d76ae0322d7/launch-425c423d843b.min.js" async></script>
            <script type="text/javascript" src="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/content/dam/pan/en_US/includes/attribution.js"></script>


<script type="text/javascript">
var isIE11 = !!navigator.userAgent.match(/Trident.*rv\:11\./);
if(isIE11){
    var polyfill = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/scripts/polyfill.min.js';
    document.write('<script type="text/javascript" src="'+polyfill+'">\x3C/script>');
}
    /**
 * String.prototype.replaceAll() polyfill
 * https://gomakethings.com/how-to-replace-a-section-of-a-string-with-another-one-with-vanilla-js/
 * @author Chris Ferdinandi
 * @license MIT
 */
if (!String.prototype.replaceAll) {
	String.prototype.replaceAll = function(str, newStr){
		// If a regex pattern
		if (Object.prototype.toString.call(str).toLowerCase() === '[object regexp]') {
			return this.replace(str, newStr);
		}
		// If a string
		return this.replace(new RegExp(str, 'g'), newStr);
	};
}

    /*! lozad.js - v1.16.0 - 2020-09-06 */
!function(t,e){"object"==typeof exports&&"undefined"!=typeof module?module.exports=e():"function"==typeof define&&define.amd?define(e):t.lozad=e()}(this,function(){"use strict";
/**
   * Detect IE browser
   * @const {boolean}
   * @private
   */var g="undefined"!=typeof document&&document.documentMode,f={rootMargin:"0px",threshold:0,load:function(t){if("picture"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()){var e=t.querySelector("img"),r=!1;null===e&&(e=document.createElement("img"),r=!0),g&&t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")&&(e.src=t.getAttribute("data-iesrc")),t.getAttribute("data-alt")&&(e.alt=t.getAttribute("data-alt")),r&&t.append(e)}if("video"===t.nodeName.toLowerCase()&&!t.getAttribute("data-src")&&t.children){for(var a=t.children,o=void 0,i=0;i<=a.length-1;i++)(o=a[i].getAttribute("data-src"))&&(a[i].src=o);t.load()}t.getAttribute("data-poster")&&(t.poster=t.getAttribute("data-poster")),t.getAttribute("data-src")&&(t.src=t.getAttribute("data-src")),t.getAttribute("data-srcset")&&t.setAttribute("srcset",t.getAttribute("data-srcset"));var n=",";if(t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")&&(n=t.getAttribute("data-background-delimiter")),t.getAttribute("data-background-image"))t.style.backgroundImage="url('"+t.getAttribute("data-background-image").split(n).join("'),url('")+"')";else if(t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set")){var d=t.getAttribute("data-background-image-set").split(n),u=d[0].substr(0,d[0].indexOf(" "))||d[0];// Substring before ... 1x
u=-1===u.indexOf("url(")?"url("+u+")":u,1===d.length?t.style.backgroundImage=u:t.setAttribute("style",(t.getAttribute("style")||"")+"background-image: "+u+"; background-image: -webkit-image-set("+d+"); background-image: image-set("+d+")")}t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class")&&t.classList.toggle(t.getAttribute("data-toggle-class"))},loaded:function(){}};function A(t){t.setAttribute("data-loaded",!0)}var m=function(t){return"true"===t.getAttribute("data-loaded")},v=function(t){var e=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:document;return t instanceof Element?[t]:t instanceof NodeList?t:e.querySelectorAll(t)};return function(){var r,a,o=0<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[0]?arguments[0]:".lozad",t=1<arguments.length&&void 0!==arguments[1]?arguments[1]:{},e=Object.assign({},f,t),i=e.root,n=e.rootMargin,d=e.threshold,u=e.load,g=e.loaded,s=void 0;"undefined"!=typeof window&&window.IntersectionObserver&&(s=new IntersectionObserver((r=u,a=g,function(t,e){t.forEach(function(t){(0<t.intersectionRatio||t.isIntersecting)&&(e.unobserve(t.target),m(t.target)||(r(t.target),A(t.target),a(t.target)))})}),{root:i,rootMargin:n,threshold:d}));for(var c,l=v(o,i),b=0;b<l.length;b++)(c=l[b]).getAttribute("data-placeholder-background")&&(c.style.background=c.getAttribute("data-placeholder-background"));return{observe:function(){for(var t=v(o,i),e=0;e<t.length;e++)m(t[e])||(s?s.observe(t[e]):(u(t[e]),A(t[e]),g(t[e])))},triggerLoad:function(t){m(t)||(u(t),A(t),g(t))},observer:s}}});

</script>

<!-- <script src="https://www.google.com/recaptcha/api.js"></script>  -->

<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

</head>
<body class="post-template-default single single-post postid-129019 single-format-standard no-sidebar">
<header class="haeder py-15 position-relative z-index-2" style="display: none;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30 px-35">
    <div class="row">
        <div class="first-logo col-sm-auto col-6 mb-sm-0 mb-40 text-sm-center order-1">
                        <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/">
                <img src="/wp-content/uploads/2021/07/PANW_Parent.png" width="140px" alt="Logo" />
            </a>
        </div>
      <div class="col-sm-auto col-6 text-sm-center order-sm-2 order-4 second-logo-unit">
        <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/">
            <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/unit42-logo-white.svg" class="attachment-full size-full" alt="Unit42 Logo"  width="150" height="35"/>
        </a>

      <div class="col-auto d-sm-none ml-auto mb-40 order-2">

<nav id="navigation" class="site-nav collapse d-sm-block pb-20 mt-sm-10"  style="display: none!important;">
  <div class="container px-sm-30">
    <ul id="menu-primary-navigation" class="main-menu d-sm-flex font-weight-medium"><li id="menu-item-97290" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-97290"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tools/">Tools</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-41" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-41"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/atoms/">ATOMs</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-119884" class="menu-item menu-item-type-custom menu-item-object-custom menu-item-119884"><a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/unit42">Security Consulting</a></li>
<li id="menu-item-81229" class="menu-item menu-item-type-post_type menu-item-object-page menu-item-81229"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/about-unit-42/">About Us</a></li>

</ul>  </div>

<div class="panClean pan-template-home" id="main-nav-menu-cont" style="display:none;">
    <div class="cleanHeader mainNavigationComp baseComponent parbase">
        <div class="productNav2021Component dark default" id="PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC">
        </div>
  </div>
<div class="cleanTopHtml htmlComp baseComponent parbase"><div class="base-component-spacer spacer-none  "></div>
</div>

<!--  Start: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->
<script type="text/javascript">
	function getCookie(cname) {
	 	var name = cname + "=";
  		var decodedCookie = decodeURIComponent(document.cookie);
		var ca = decodedCookie.split(';');
  		for(var i = 0; i <ca.length; i++) {
    			var c = ca[i];
    			while (c.charAt(0) == ' ') {
     				 c = c.substring(1);
    			}
    			if (c.indexOf(name) == 0) {
    				 return c.substring(name.length, c.length);
    			}
  		}
  		return "";
	}

	var referer = "";//sessionStorage.container;
	var pcontainer = sessionStorage.getItem("container");
	var searchResultsPagePath = "";
	if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Prisma')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Prisma' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Cortex')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Cortex' ;
	}
        else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Sase')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Sase' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Unit')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Unit' ;
	}
	else if(((pcontainer) && pcontainer.indexOf('Ngfw')!=-1)){
	    referer = 'Ngfw' ;
	}
        var fromRef = document.referrer;
        var nContainer = getCookie("navContainer");
        if(nContainer){//If user is coming from main site, we need to reset the container		
		if(fromRef  && fromRef.indexOf("prismacloud.io")!=-1){
                        referer = 'Prisma' ;
                        sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                } else if(fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.com")!=-1 || fromRef.indexOf("paloaltonetworks.jp")!=-1 ){
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Prisma') != -1){
                            referer = 'Prisma' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Prisma");
                        }
                        if(nContainer.indexOf('Cortex') != -1){
                            referer = 'Cortex' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Cortex");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Sase') != -1){
                            referer = 'Sase' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Sase");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Unit') != -1){
                            referer = 'Unit' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
                        }
			if(nContainer.indexOf('Ngfw') != -1){
                            referer = 'Ngfw' ;
                            sessionStorage.setItem("container","Ngfw");
                        }
			document.cookie = 'navContainer=; path=/; domain=.paloaltonetworks.com; expires=' + new Date(0).toUTCString();
		}
	}
if(referer != "Prisma" && referer != "Cortex" && referer != "Sase" && referer != "Unit" && referer != "Ngfw") {
    referer = 'Unit' ;
    sessionStorage.setItem("container","Unit");
}
function callMainSitePrismaNavHTML(){
    
    var referrer_domain = 'https://www.paloaltonetworks.com';
    sessionStorage.setItem("domain",referrer_domain);
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderPrisma.prismaRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/prismasearch";
        }
    if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderCortex.cortexRenderer.html';	
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/cortexsearch";	
    }
    if(referer == 'Sase'){
        var menu_url = referrer_domain+'/_jcr_content/globals/cleanHeaderSase.saseRenderer.html';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/sasesearch";
    }
    if(referer == 'Unit'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/unit-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/content/pan/en_US/search/unit42search";
		    }
    if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        var menu_url = 'https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/ngfw-cdss-nav-renderer.php';
        searchResultsPagePath = referrer_domain+"/search/ngfwcdsssearch";
    }
    httpGet(menu_url,'menu_html');
    document.getElementById('main-nav-menu-cont').removeAttribute("style");
}
function addStyle(styles) {            
    /* Create style document */
    var css = document.createElement('style');
    css.type = 'text/css';

    if (css.styleSheet) 
        css.styleSheet.cssText = styles;
    else 
        css.appendChild(document.createTextNode(styles));

    /* Append style to the tag name */
    document.getElementsByTagName("head")[0].appendChild(css);
}
function httpGet(theUrl,req_type) {
    if (window.XMLHttpRequest) { // code for IE7+, Firefox, Chrome, Opera, Safari
        xmlhttp=new XMLHttpRequest();
    } else {// code for IE6, IE5
        xmlhttp=new ActiveXObject("Microsoft.XMLHTTP");
    }
    xmlhttp.onreadystatechange=function()
    {
        if (xmlhttp.readyState==4 && xmlhttp.status==200)
        {
            if(req_type == 'menu_html'){
            var nav_text = xmlhttp.responseText.replaceAll('https://static.cloud.coveo.com/searchui/v2.9159/js/CoveoJsSearch.Lazy.min.js', '');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll('src="/', 'src="'+maindomain_lang+'/');
            nav_text = nav_text.replaceAll("'/content", "'"+maindomain_lang+"/content");
                        
            document.getElementById("PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC").innerHTML = nav_text.replaceAll('href="/', 'href="'+maindomain_lang+'/');

            var lozad_back = document.getElementsByClassName('lozad-background');
            Array.prototype.forEach.call(lozad_back, function(el) {
            // Do stuff here
            var el_back_img_path = el.getAttribute('data-background-image');
            var first_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'");
            var last_pos = el_back_img_path.indexOf("'",first_pos+1);
            el_back_img_path = el_back_img_path.substring(first_pos+1,last_pos);
            el.setAttribute("data-background-image",main_site_url+el_back_img_path);
            });
            }
            if(req_type == 'head_inline_css'){
            addStyle(xmlhttp.responseText);
            }
        }
    }
    xmlhttp.open("GET", theUrl, true );
    xmlhttp.send();    
}    
    
if(referer == 'Prisma' || referer == 'Cortex' || referer == 'Sase' || referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
    const article = document.querySelector('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC');
    if(referer == 'Prisma'){
        article.dataset.type = 'prisma';
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    else if(referer == 'Cortex'){
        article.dataset.type = 'cortex';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Sase'){
        article.dataset.type = 'sase';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Unit'){
        article.dataset.type = 'unit';
    }
    else if(referer == 'Ngfw'){
        article.dataset.type = 'ngfw';
    }
    //set class to default
    if(referer == 'Unit' || referer == 'Ngfw'){
        $('#PAN_2021_NAV_ASYNC').removeClass('default').addClass('defaultRedesigned');
    }
    callMainSitePrismaNavHTML();        
}
</script>
<!--  End: Scripts Migrated From Unit42-v5 -->

    <section class="section section--article">
        <div class="pa article-banner" style="background-image:url('https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/11_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900.jpg')">
          <div class="l-container"> 
            <div class="l-breadcrumbs"> 
              <ul> <li> <a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="malicious-packages-in-pypi:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research Center</a></li><li><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/threat-research/" role="link" title="Threat Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="malicious-packages-in-pypi:hero:breadcrumb:Threat Research">Threat Research</a></li><li class="is-current"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cloud-cybersecurity-research/" role="link" title="Cloud Cybersecurity Research" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="malicious-packages-in-pypi:hero:breadcrumb:Cloud Cybersecurity Research">Cloud Cybersecurity Research</a></li> </ul>

              <a class="card-category" href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cloud-cybersecurity-research/" role="link" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="malicious-packages-in-pypi:hero:Cloud Cybersecurity Research"><span class="ab-title__pre">Cloud Cybersecurity Research</span></a> 
              <h1>Six Malicious Python Packages in the PyPI Targeting Windows Users</h1>

				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fmalicious-packages-in-pypi%2F&#038;text=Six%20Malicious%20Python%20Packages%20in%20the%20PyPI%20Targeting%20Windows%20Users" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Twitter" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="malicious-packages-in-pypi:share:twitter"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-twitter-share.svg" alt="Twitter Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="//www.reddit.com/submit?url=https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fmalicious-packages-in-pypi%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Reddit" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="malicious-packages-in-pypi:share:reddit"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-reddit-share.svg" alt="Reddit Icon"></a>
				</li>
				<li role="menuitem">
					<a href="https://mastodon.social/share?text=Six%20Malicious%20Python%20Packages%20in%20the%20PyPI%20Targeting%20Windows%20Users%20https%3A%2F%2Funit42.paloaltonetworks.com%2Fmalicious-packages-in-pypi%2F" target="_blank" role="link" title="Share in Mastodon" data-page-track="true" data-page-track-value="malicious-packages-in-pypi:share:mastodon"> <img src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/themes/unit42-v6/dist/images/icons/icon-mastodon-share.svg" alt="Mastodon Icon"></a>
				</li>
	  </ul>
    </div>                </div>
              </div>
            </div>
          </div>
        </div>
      </section> 
    <section class="section blog-contents"> 
      <div class="pa blog-editor">
        <div class="l-container">
          <div class="be__wrapper">
            <div class="be__contents">
              <div class="be__contents-wrapper">
                <p class="wpml-ls-statics-post_translations wpml-ls">This post is also available in: 
    <span class="wpml-ls-slot-post_translations wpml-ls-item wpml-ls-item-ja wpml-ls-first-item wpml-ls-last-item wpml-ls-item-legacy-post-translations"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.jp/malicious-packages-in-pypi/" class="wpml-ls-link"><span class="wpml-ls-native" lang="ja">日本語</span><span class="wpml-ls-display"><span class="wpml-ls-bracket"> (</span>Japanese<span class="wpml-ls-bracket">)</span></span></a></span></p><h2><a id="post-129019-_ftey9dkn0q0f"></a>Executive Summary</h2>
<p>In March 2023, Unit 42 researchers discovered six malicious packages on the Python Package Index (PyPI) package manager. The malicious packages were intended to steal Windows users’ application credentials, personal data and tracking information for their crypto wallets. The attack was an attempted imitation of the attack group W4SP, which had previously launched several supply chain attacks using malicious packages.</p>
<p>We will discuss the ease with which threat actors can use malicious packages to release malicious code in an open-source ecosystem. The behavior we observed is not an organized campaign planned by an attack group, but most likely an imitator who read technical reports of previous campaigns to execute their own attack. We will walk through a technical analysis of the malicious code and unravel what the threat actor tried to achieve in the attack.</p>
<p>We will describe the indicators used by Palo Alto Networks Prisma Cloud modules that identified the malicious packages discussed here. Palo Alto Networks customers receive protections from open-source packages containing malicious code via Prisma Cloud.</p>
<table style="width: 100%;">
<thead>
<tr>
<td style="width: 35%;"><b>Related Unit 42 Topics</b></td>
<td style="width: 100%;"><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/category/cloud/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><b>Cloud</b></a>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/Python/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Python</a></strong>, <strong><a href="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/tag/open-source/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Open Source</a></strong></td>
</tr>
</thead>
</table>
<h2><a id="post-129019-_by1wt6yuxz57"></a>Overview</h2>
<p>Malicious packages are software components that were intentionally designed to cause harm to computer systems or the data they process. Such packages can be distributed through various means, including phishing emails, compromised websites or even legitimate software repositories.</p>
<p>Malicious packages can have far-reaching consequences, from surreptitiously pilfering sensitive data to causing system disruptions and even assuming control over entire systems. Moreover, these nefarious packages possess the ability to spread to other interconnected systems, instigating widespread damage and impeding productivity. Thus, it is important to exercise utmost caution when engaging in software downloads and installations, especially when the source is unfamiliar or untrusted.</p>
<p>By remaining vigilant and discerning, users can safeguard their systems and prevent potential harm from threat actors infiltrating their technological environment.</p>
<h2><a id="post-129019-_nmdyhkx8zzp3"></a>New Malicious Packages Discovered in PyPI</h2>
<p>In March 2023, Prisma Cloud researchers discovered six malicious packages on the <a href="https://pypi.org/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">PyPI package manager</a> targeting Windows users. The malicious packages were intended to steal application credentials, personal data and cryptocurrency wallet information.</p>
<p>Our Prisma Cloud engine, designed to detect malicious PyPI packages, identified several packages with suspicious attributes that were uploaded within a short time frame:</p>
<ul>
<li>The packages lacked an associated GitHub repository, which is commonly found with legitimate packages. This could indicate a desire to hide the code from view. This, coupled with a limited number of downloads, further raised our suspicions.</li>
<li>When executed, the packages performed malicious actions such as collecting sensitive data and sending it to third-party URLs.</li>
<li>The packages contained a malicious code pattern (as will be demonstrated later), which was detected by our engine.</li>
<li>Because the package authors were newly created, had only uploaded one package, and did not provide supporting information such as links to other projects or to any repository, they were not considered reputable.</li>
<li>Finally, the usernames of the packages’ author(s) were created within minutes of each other, following a distinctive pattern (e.g., Anne1337, Richard1337). Each of these usernames had uploaded only a single package.</li>
</ul>
<p>The second stage of the attack was similar to previous attacks we have seen by the <a href="https://thehackernews.com/2022/11/w4sp-stealer-constantly-targeting.html" target="_blank" rel="noopener">W4SP </a>attack group. This group specializes in exploiting vulnerabilities in the open-source ecosystem, targeting organizations and spreading malware. Their primary goal is to gain unauthorized access to sensitive information, such as user credentials and financial data. They often use automated tools to scan for vulnerabilities and attempt to exploit them. In addition to traditional attacks, W4SP attackers were also seen executing supply chain attacks.</p>
<h2><a id="post-129019-_17mzw2ogwwbp"></a>Findings</h2>
<p>Prisma Cloud engine detected the packages that were marked as potentially containing malicious code. Each package contained a link to a suspicious remote URL, trying to download contents after having been uploaded individually by a single user.</p>
<p>The users for each uploaded package, whose usernames were created just before the upload, didn’t have any history of previously uploading packages. Each package reached hundreds of downloads, until they and the fraudulent user accounts that uploaded them were removed by PyPI due to our research team reporting the abuse.</p>
<p>We analyzed the code and tried to track down the package authors. We discovered a pattern in every package author’s username where they used “1337” as a suffix, which indicates that some automatic process created those users, as shown in Table 1. Figure 1 shows an author page for one of these usernames.</p>
<table style="width: 100.378%;">
<tbody>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.8054%; text-align: center;"><b>Package Name</b></td>
<td style="width: 18.5725%; text-align: center;"><b>Author </b></td>
<td style="width: 43.9754%; text-align: center;"><b>Malicious Link</b></td>
<td style="width: 24.1443%; text-align: center;"><b>Number of Downloads</b></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.8054%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">ligitgays</span></td>
<td style="width: 18.5725%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anne1337</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.9754%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://paste.bingner[.]com/paste/o27gb/raw</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.1443%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">191</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.8054%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">xboxredeemer</span></td>
<td style="width: 18.5725%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Richard1337</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.9754%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxps://paste.bingner[.]com/paste/47rpu/raw</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.1443%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">160</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.8054%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">syntax-init</span></td>
<td style="width: 18.5725%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Debbie1337</span></td>

<td style="width: 24.1443%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">140</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.8054%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">xboxlivepy</span></td>
<td style="width: 18.5725%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Christopher1337</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.9754%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://paste.bingner[.]com/paste/jr7ow/raw</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.1443%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">153</span></td>
</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.8054%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Ligitkidss</span></td>
<td style="width: 18.5725%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Sara1337</span></td>

</tr>
<tr>
<td style="width: 21.8054%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">tls-python</span></td>
<td style="width: 18.5725%;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Kevin1337</span></td>
<td style="width: 43.9754%;"><span style="font-weight: 400; font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://paste.bingner[.]com/paste/97vnn/raw</span></td>
<td style="width: 24.1443%; text-align: center;"><span style="font-weight: 400;">240</span></td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p style="text-align: center;"><a id="post-129019-_gjdgxs"></a><span style="font-size: 10pt; color: #999999;"><em>Table 1. Malicious package findings.</em></span></p>
<figure id="attachment_129040" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129040" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129040" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129019-1-1.png" alt="Image 1 is a screenshot of an author page on PyPI. The user has not uploaded any projects. The name of the user is Travis Elliott, they joined March 13, 2023, and their user name is Richard1337." width="900" height="574" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129040" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 1. An author page on PyPI.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-129019-_c1c2rtaijnya"></a><strong>The Attack: Custom Package Entry Point</strong></h2>
<p>The attack was similar to previous attacks we have seen by the W4SP attack group, which was covered in detail in the Bleeping Computer article, “<a href="https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/devs-targeted-by-w4sp-stealer-malware-in-malicious-pypi-packages/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Devs targeted by W4SP Stealer malware in malicious PyPi packages</a>.” These similarities led us to believe this was a copycat attack.</p>
<p>There were aspects of this case that were less complex than we would expect for a true W4SP attack, for example:</p>
<ul>
<li>There was no targeting of any organization.</li>
<li>The malicious packages did not use typosquatting for common popular packages, as expected for W4SP attacks.</li>
<li>The second phase of the attack was not encrypted. In the true attacks from W4SP, this phase was encrypted and it made detection more difficult.</li>
<li>Most of the code used by W4SP for previous attacks was already available for download, so it could be easily accessed and repurposed.</li>
</ul>
<p>In the previous attack, W4SP Stealer was delivered as a second stage payload downloaded from a free file hosting service, which allowed the attacker to avoid detection at the package repository itself.</p>
<p>Rather than containing overtly malicious code, these packages were crafted to have specific entry points that would be triggered during the installation or execution process. By leveraging free file hosting services and employing custom entry points, the attackers aimed to remain undetected, posing a significant challenge to security professionals and researchers tasked with detecting and mitigating such threats.</p>
<p>These attacks are easy to implement and can be launched with little security expertise. However, they can be very effective, as the installation process automatically executes the attack as opposed to a threat actor needing to launch the attack when the imported module is used.</p>
<p>When a software developer wants to use a Python package they have to perform two actions. The first is to install the package, and the second is to import or declare in the code to use it. As we discuss in the next section, the attack code actually starts in the installation file (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">setup.py</span>), which means that the attack is already carried out during the installation of the package.</p>
<p>In the case we investigated, the attacker called themself @EVIL$ STEALER. However, the attacker’s name changed with every attack. Below is the collection of names, as found in the code signature:</p>
<ul>
<li>ANGEL Stealer</li>
<li>Celestial Stealer</li>
<li>Fade Stealer</li>
<li>Leaf $tealer</li>
<li>PURE Stealer</li>
<li>Satan Stealer</li>
<li>@skid Stealer</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-129019-_wri84ait79zd"></a>Malicious Code</h3>
<p>The <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">setup.py</span> file was the same in all packages and contained the following code snippet that downloads content from a remote URL before executing it:</p>
<figure id="attachment_129042" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129042" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129042" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129019-2-1.png" alt="Image 2 is a screenshot of many lines of python code. This code snippet downloads content from a remote URL before executing it." width="900" height="503" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129042" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 2. Setup.py (first stage) malicious code.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Figure 2 (above) shows the following activities:</p>
<ol>
<li>The attacker uses the<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;"> _ffile</span> object to create a temporary file, and the contents of the file are written using the write method.
<ul>
<li>The usage of a temporary file with the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">NamedTemporaryFile</span> function is a well-known technique to hide malicious code from detection by antivirus software or other security measures.</li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>The file's contents are obtained by downloading the contents of a URL using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">urlopen</span> function from the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">urllib.request</span> module, and then executes the contents of the file using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">exec</span> function.</li>
<li>After the contents of the temporary file have been written, the file is closed and an attempt is made to execute it using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">start</span> command in the system shell. If this is successful, the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">setup</span> function is called to create the package.
<ul>
<li>The attacker then uses the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">start</span> command to start the Python engine's executable (<span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">pythonw.exe</span>).</li>
<li>This executable will then execute the script file that is passed as a parameter. Since that malicious package targeted Windows users, if the script file is not signed, it will not be subject to SmartScreen (Windows security feature to detect and prevent the execution of potentially malicious files) or signature checking.</li>
<li>This means it will execute malicious code on a target computer, even if the target computer has SmartScreen and signature checking enabled.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
<h3><a id="post-129019-_sxafpt6e1ssg"></a>The Second Stage: W4SP Stealer</h3>
<p>According to our research, for the second stage, the attacker used a configured version of W4SP Stealer 1.1.6. This version is similar to previous ones where the code imports several libraries, including <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">requests</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">Crypto.Cipher</span>, <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">json</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">sqlite3</span>. Then, it uses various techniques to extract and decrypt stored browser credentials, including passwords and cookies, and sends this information to a Discord webhook.</p>
<p>This stage was similar within all of the malicious packages found. The W4SP Stealer is <a href="https://www.bleepingcomputer.com/news/security/dozens-of-pypi-packages-caught-dropping-w4sp-info-stealing-malware/?ref=blog.phylum.io" target="_blank" rel="noopener">well known by the cybersecurity community</a>. This section will give a short overview.</p>
<p>The main body of the code defines a class <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DATA_BLOB</span>, which is used to store data for the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CryptUnprotectData</span> function. This function decrypts a Windows Data Protection API (DPAPI)-protected value, which is used to store sensitive data such as passwords and API keys. The code attempts to decrypt a value using the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">CryptUnprotectData</span> and <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DecryptValue</span> functions, and then sends it to a remote server via a Discord webhook, as shown in Figure 3.</p>
<figure id="attachment_129044" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129044" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129044" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129019-3-1.png" alt="Image 3 is a screenshot of many lines of code. It first defines the DATA_BLOB class before attempting to decrypt a value." width="900" height="775" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129044" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 3. Attempts to decrypt a Windows Data Protection API (DPAPI)-protected value.</figcaption></figure>
<p>The figures below show several examples from the malicious code in which the attacker tries to collect information about the victim. In Figure 4, the attacker tries to collect information about the victim including IP address, username, country and country code.</p>
<figure id="attachment_129046" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129046" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129046" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129019-4-1.png" alt="Image 4 is a screenshot of code that retrieved information about the user’s IP address, location, and user name along with country code, country name, and other information." width="900" height="347" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129046" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 4. Code that retrieves information about the user's IP address, location and username among other things.</figcaption></figure>
<p>In Figure 5, the attacker interacts with the Discord API to retrieve a user's friend list and extract information about their owned badge.</p>
<figure id="attachment_129048" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129048" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129048" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129019-5-1.png" alt="Image 5 is a screenshot of code that retrieves a list of a user’s friend on Discord, which is an application that acts like a custom chat room. These chat rooms are called channels." width="900" height="533" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129048" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 5. Code to retrieve a list of a user's friends on Discord.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Later in code, they try to use a Discord webhook prepared in advance (shown in Figure 6) and then they try to send the victim information via HTTP requests to the associated Discord channel.</p>
<figure id="attachment_129050" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129050" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129050" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129019-6-1.png" alt="Image 6 is a screenshot of a Discord API webhook. " width="900" height="95" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129050" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 6. Discord webhook.</figcaption></figure>
<p>Finally, as shown in Figure 7, the attacker tries to verify whether the victim's machine is suitable for carrying out the attack. If it’s determined that the machine is suitable, the <span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">DETECTED</span> variable will be set to true and the information from the victim's machine will be sent to the remote server.</p>
<figure id="attachment_129052" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129052" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129052" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129019-7-1.png" alt="Image 7 is a screenshot of code that can search for cookies." width="900" height="305" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129052" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 7. Code searching for cookies.</figcaption></figure>
<h2><a id="post-129019-_p8jkqzv0hiiz"></a>PyPI as a Convenient Platform for Uploading Malicious Packages</h2>
<p>Within the realm of PyPI, which is a revered and widely embraced repository that hosts a staggering number of Python packages, a disconcerting reality has emerged. The repository's unrivaled popularity has inadvertently attracted the attention of unscrupulous entities, fervently seeking to exploit its vast user base by surreptitiously disseminating malicious packages.</p>
<p>This distressing trend poses a paramount challenge, as the decentralized nature of PyPI renders the monitoring and detection of these malevolent entities an arduous endeavor. The ramifications of falling victim to such nefarious packages are profound, posing severe consequences for unsuspecting users and enterprises alike, such as data, credential or crypto theft. Hence, fortifying the safety and security of PyPI's package ecosystem assumes a critical imperative, necessitating the implementation of robust countermeasures to combat this persistent threat.</p>
<p>As a result of this, it was not surprising that on May 20, 2023, <a href="https://status.python.org/incidents/qy2t9mjjcc7g" target="_blank" rel="noopener">PyPI announced</a> that they temporarily suspended the registration and upload of new packages due to a concerning rise in malicious activities, malicious users and projects on the platform. Unfortunately, no specific information about the nature of the malware or the threat actors involved has been disclosed at this time.</p>
<p>This decision to freeze new user and project registrations reflects the ongoing challenges software registries like PyPI face, as they have become attractive targets for attackers seeking to compromise developer environments and tamper with the software supply chain.</p>
<h2><a id="post-129019-_oq1662b0xhzl"></a>Conclusion</h2>
<p>The rise and prevalence of open-source software and the proliferation of package managers have made it easier than ever for attackers to slip these dangerous packages into unsuspecting systems. With software becoming increasingly pervasive in our daily lives, the threat of malicious packages has become more significant. Attackers can disguise these packages as legitimate software and exploit vulnerabilities in unsuspecting systems, causing significant damage such as data theft, system shutdown and network control.</p>
<p>To combat this threat, software developers and organizations must prioritize software security in their development process. Implementing robust security measures, such as code reviews, automated testing and penetration testing can help identify and remediate vulnerabilities before deployment. Additionally, staying up to date with security patches and updates can prevent attackers from exploiting known vulnerabilities.</p>
<p>In addition to technical measures, increasing awareness and education around software security can also help mitigate the risk of malicious packages. Regular training for developers, IT staff and end users on best security practices (e.g., password hygiene and suspicious email identification) can help prevent successful attacks. The collective effort of security professionals, developers and end users is necessary to ensure that malicious packages are identified and prevented from causing harm to systems and networks.</p>
<p>Publishing technical reports about malware and malicious packages also plays a critical role in advancing our understanding of these threats and improving our ability to protect against them. Technical reports provide an in-depth analysis of the behavior and functionality of malware, which helps researchers and security professionals develop more effective countermeasures. Additionally, sharing technical details about malware can help organizations stay up to date with the latest threats and vulnerabilities, allowing them to improve their security posture and reduce the risk of cyberattacks.</p>
<h2><a id="post-129019-_1i663fdmju7j"></a><strong>Palo Alto Networks Product Protections</strong></h2>
<p><strong>Prisma Cloud Runtime Protection Solution </strong></p>
<p>Prisma Cloud runtime defenses involve a configurable set of features that provide the identification of specified and predictive protections for cloud virtual machines, containers and serverless functions. Predictive protections include capabilities like determining when a cloud or container instance executes an unknown process or creates an unexpected network socket.</p>
<p>Threat-based protections include capabilities like detecting when malware is added to a workload, or when a workload connects to a botnet. This detection of malicious binaries is made possible through the integration of the Palo Alto Networks <a href="https://www.paloaltonetworks.com/network-security/wildfire" target="_blank" rel="noopener">WildFire</a> cloud-based malware protection engine. These runtime incidents can also be detected predeployment, using the Image Analysis Sandbox.</p>
<p><strong>Prisma Cloud Malicious Package Solution</strong></p>
<p>Prisma Cloud offers an advanced end-to-end cybersecurity solution that encompasses a comprehensive suite of proactive measures designed to safeguard Prisma customers against a wide array of potential attacks, mitigating risks well in advance of their public exposure.</p>
<p>At the heart of this cutting-edge defense system lies the Prisma CVE Viewer, a dynamic resource that operates in real-time, continuously updated to reflect the latest threat landscape.</p>
<p>Incorporating a unique identification system known as Prisma-IDs, this viewer serves as a central repository for public vulnerabilities meticulously unearthed by our diligent research team. Leveraging this proprietary identifier, it bridges the gap for vulnerabilities that have yet to receive a Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVE) ID, ensuring no security gaps go unnoticed or unaddressed. Moreover, the Prisma CVE Viewer diligently archives any malicious packages discovered by our expert researchers, empowering Prisma customers with unparalleled visibility into potential threats lurking within their software supply chain.</p>
<p>As shown in Figure 8, by arming customers with Prisma-IDs and equipping them with preemptive protection, Prisma Cloud protects against possible exploits before they have an opportunity to materialize. This robust security approach serves as a formidable deterrent against supply chain attacks, proactively thwarting threats and preserving the integrity and resilience of our customers' systems and infrastructure.</p>
<figure id="attachment_129054" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129054" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129054" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129019-8-1.png" alt="Image 8 is a screenshot of the Prisma Cloud application. It is the CVE viewer. It has detected a malicious package in its CVE database. There is a search field, and then a table displaying the CVE, package, distro, release, CVSS score, which is 7.5, the severity, which is high, the affected versions, and when it was modified in IS." width="900" height="223" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129054" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 8. Prisma Cloud detection.</figcaption></figure>
<p>On top of that, the new Prisma Cloud CI/CD Security module (shown in Figure 9) offers comprehensive protection against emerging methods of executing code in CI pipelines and developers’ environments through malicious software dependencies (e.g., dependency confusion, typosquatting and compromised known packages). This is done by analyzing the different settings, configurations and interconnections of the various systems across the software delivery pipelines, such as the version control and CI systems.</p>
<figure id="attachment_129056" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-129056" style="width: 900px" class="wp-caption aligncenter"><img decoding="async" class="wp-image-129056" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/07/word-image-129019-9-1.png" alt="Image 9 is a screenshot of the Prisma Cloud CI/CD Security module. It is a dashboard with many different statistics displaying a wide range of data. " width="900" height="504" /><figcaption id="caption-attachment-129056" class="wp-caption-text">Figure 9. Prisma Cloud CI/CD Security module.</figcaption></figure>
<p><strong>Cortex EDR analytics</strong></p>
<p>Cortex XDR provides EDR analytics capabilities on top of Cortex XDR agents, thus providing analytics-based detection capabilities for runtime command and control (C2) detection of malicious Python packages being used at runtime. An example for EDR analytics C2 coverage is discussed in our Cortex XDR technical documentation. See the Variant subsection <a href="https://docs-cortex.paloaltonetworks.com/r/Cortex-XDR-Analytics-Alert-Reference/A-process-connected-to-a-rare-external-host" target="_blank" rel="noopener">“UNIX LOLBIN process connected to a rare external host”</a> under the "A process connected to a rare external host" section.</p>
<h3><a id="post-129019-_47el3g9xmcir"></a>Indicators of Compromise</h3>
<h3><a id="post-129019-_wyxia2jhw9u9"></a>Malicious Packages</h3>
<ul>
<li>ligitgays</li>
<li>xboxredeemer</li>
<li>syntax-init</li>
<li>xboxlivepy</li>
<li>Ligitkidss</li>
<li>Tls-python</li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-129019-_wcydp56p1lil"></a><br />
Malicious URLs</h3>
<ul>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://paste.bingner[.]com/paste/o27gb/raw</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxps://paste.bingner[.]com/paste/47rpu/raw</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://paste.bingner[.]com/paste/q77t3/raw</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://paste.bingner[.]com/paste/jr7ow/raw</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://paste.bingner[.]com/paste/9mzzs/raw</span></li>
<li><span style="font-family: 'courier new', courier, monospace;">hxxps://paste.bingner[.]com/paste/97vnn/raw</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><a id="post-129019-_rc8i61ab0s3"></a>Malicious Users</h3>
<ul>
<li><a href="https://pypi.org/user/Anne1337/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Anne1337</a></li>
<li><a href="https://pypi.org/user/Richard1337/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Richard1337</a></li>
<li><a href="https://pypi.org/user/Debbie1337/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Debbie1337</a></li>
<li><a href="https://pypi.org/user/Christopher1337/" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Christopher1337</a></li>
<li><a href="https://pypi.org/user/Sara1337" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Sara1337</a></li>
<li><a href="https://pypi.org/user/Kevin1337" target="_blank" rel="noopener">Kevin1337</a></li>
</ul>
<p><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Updated July 14, 2023, at 9:15 a.m. PT to add more context to the code in Figure 2. </span></i></p>
      
              </div>

                <img width="786" height="368" src="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/01_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-786x368.jpg" class="attachment-medium size-medium" alt="Illustration of a futuristic city with glowing orange and blue lights, surrounded by clouds and digital elements, conveying a high-tech, cybernetic theme." decoding="async" srcset="https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/01_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-786x368.jpg 786w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/01_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-1493x700.jpg 1493w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/01_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-768x360.jpg 768w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/01_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900-1536x720.jpg 1536w, https://unit42.paloaltonetworks.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/06/01_Cloud_cybersecurity_research_Overview_1920x900.jpg 1920w" sizes="(max-width: 786px) 100vw, 786px" />                </figure>
